elements.content: A flexible tetrapodal octacarboxylate ligand with four 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate units has been used to construct three polyhedral metal–organic frameworks, which show a (4,8)-connected structure of a rare scu topology comprising octahedral and cuboctahedral cages.
elements.clean_text: A flexible tetrapodal octacarboxylate ligand with four 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate units has been used to construct three polyhedral metal-organic frameworks, which show a (4,8)-connected structure of a rare scu topology comprising octahedral and cuboctahedral cages.

elements.content: A flexible tetrapodal octacarboxylate ligand with four 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate units has been used to construct three polyhedral metal−organic frameworks, which show a (4,8)-connected structure of a rare scu topology comprising octahedral and cuboctahedral cages.
elements.clean_text: A flexible tetrapodal octacarboxylate ligand with four 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate units has been used to construct three polyhedral metal-organic frameworks, which show a (4,8)-connected structure of a rare scu topology comprising octahedral and cuboctahedral cages.

elements.content: In recent years, the rational design and assembly of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have received remarkable attention in order to develop new functional materials with various potential applications. Gaining an understanding of network topologies is important and essential because it not only provides a facile approach to simplify complicated networks but also plays an instructive role in the rational design of certain functional materials with desirable properties. MOFs with various network topologies can be designed and prepared using a simple node and linker approach. To date, a large number of MOFs have been reported, which usually possess low-connected uninodal network with three-, four-, and six-connected topologies. At the same time, some MOFs with mixed connected topologies have also been reported, for example, Pt3O4, boracite, PtS, rutile, pyrite, and anatase. However, because of severe hampering by the number of available coordination sites at the metal centers and the sterically demanding nature of the organic ligands, there is a disappointing lack of systematic investigations on binodal highly connected structures, such as (3,6)-, (4,6)-, and (4,8)-connected frameworks. It is a great challenge to achieve MOFs based on binodal highly connected nets in coordination chemistry.
elements.clean_text: In recent years, the rational design and assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received remarkable attention in order to develop new functional materials with various potential applications. Gaining an understanding of network topologies is important and essential because it not only provides a facile approach to simplify complicated networks but also plays an instructive role in the rational design of certain functional materials with desirable properties. MOFs with various network topologies can be designed and prepared using a simple node and linker approach. To date, a large number of MOFs have been reported, which usually possess low-connected uninodal network with three-, four-, and six-connected topologies. At the same time, some MOFs with mixed connected topologies have also been reported, for example, Pt3O4, boracite, PtS, rutile, pyrite, and anatase. However, because of severe hampering by the number of available coordination sites at the metal centers and the sterically demanding nature of the organic ligands, there is a disappointing lack of systematic investigations on binodal highly connected structures, such as (3,6)-, (4,6)-, and (4,8)-connected frameworks. It is a great challenge to achieve MOFs based on binodal highly connected nets in coordination chemistry.

elements.content: Recently, the utilization of metal clusters as nodes in place of a single-metal ion has provided a promising strategy toward the construction of highly connected MOFs. In particular, high-nuclear clusters, such as hexa-, hepta-, octa-, and larger ones, not only can possibly form novel highly connected topological nets but also can avoid interpenetration to increase porosity. However, it is difficult to capture, even hardly to predesign, the high-nuclear metal clusters apart from trigonal prism trinuclear M3O(COO)6 and tetranuclear zinc cluster Zn4O(COO)6 SBUs up to now.
elements.clean_text: Recently, the utilization of metal clusters as nodes in place of a single-metal ion has provided a promising strategy toward the construction of highly connected MOFs. In particular, high-nuclear clusters, such as hexa-, hepta-, octa-, and larger ones, not only can possibly form novel highly connected topological nets but also can avoid interpenetration to increase porosity. However, it is difficult to capture, even hardly to predesign, the high-nuclear metal clusters apart from trigonal prism trinuclear M3O(COO)6 and tetranuclear zinc cluster Zn4O(COO)6 SBUs up to now.

<title>Tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenoxy)methyl]methane, <bold>H</bold>
<sub>
<bold>8</bold>

elements.clean_text: 1  Tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenoxy)methyl]methane, H  8  X

elements.content: In our recent work, we found that the flexible tetrahedrally branched multicarboxylate ligand has small steric hindrance. If we can synthesize multidentate ligand as higher-connected vertices, higher-connected frameworks can be expected. Taking these into consideration, we chose the flexible tetrahedrally branched octacarboxylate ligand H 8 X (scheme ) as linkers based on the following considerations: the four −CH2–O- spacers, which link the 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) units to the central carbon atom in a tetrahedrally branched way, endow the whole ligand certain flexibility and effectively decrease the steric hindrance between the four bdc units; the bdc units, which are well-known as a primary building unit for the construction of MOFs, can be used conveniently to construct paddle-wheel SBUs [M2(COO)2, M = Cu(II), Zn(II), Cd(II)] acting as four-connected planar vertices. Hence, the (4,8)-connected net with scu (square planar and cubical vertices) topology can be expected.
elements.clean_text: In our recent work, we found that the flexible tetrahedrally branched multicarboxylate ligand has small steric hindrance. If we can synthesize multidentate ligand as higher-connected vertices, higher-connected frameworks can be expected. Taking these into consideration, we chose the flexible tetrahedrally branched octacarboxylate ligand H  8  X (scheme ) as linkers based on the following considerations: the four -CH2-O- spacers, which link the 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) units to the central carbon atom in a tetrahedrally branched way, endow the whole ligand certain flexibility and effectively decrease the steric hindrance between the four bdc units; the bdc units, which are well-known as a primary building unit for the construction of MOFs, can be used conveniently to construct paddle-wheel SBUs [M2(COO)2, M = Cu(II), Zn(II), Cd(II)] acting as four-connected planar vertices. Hence, the (4,8)-connected net with scu (square planar and cubical vertices) topology can be expected.

elements.content: (a) View of [Zn2(COO)4] paddle wheels (represented as red rectangles) and their connectivity with the X 8– ligands (represented as a blue rectangular prism) in 2; (b) a simplified connectivity scheme of 2 showing the scu topology.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of [Zn2(COO)4] paddle wheels (represented as red rectangles) and their connectivity with the X 8- ligands (represented as a blue rectangular prism) in 2; (b) a simplified connectivity scheme of 2 showing the scu topology.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O/Zn(NO3)2·6H2O/Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with H 8 X (tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenoxy)methyl]methane) in dimethylformamide (DMF) under acidic (HNO3) conditions afforded three compounds, [Cu4X(H2O)4]·7.5DMF·8H2O (1), [Zn4X(H2O)4]·8DMF·8H2O (2), and [Cd4X(DMF)6]·1.5DMF·3H2O (3), respectively. Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies unambiguously confirmed the framework structures of 1–3, where a combination of NMR, elemental analysis (EA), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) gave the number of solvent molecules in the compounds. The bulk purities of the products were independently confirmed from EA and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O/Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O/Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O with H  8  X (tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenoxy)methyl]methane) in dimethylformamide (DMF) under acidic (HNO3) conditions afforded three compounds, [Cu4X(H2O)4]⋅7.5DMF⋅8H2O (1), [Zn4X(H2O)4]⋅8DMF⋅8H2O (2), and [Cd4X(DMF)6]⋅1.5DMF⋅3H2O (3), respectively. Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies unambiguously confirmed the framework structures of 1-3, where a combination of NMR, elemental analysis (EA), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) gave the number of solvent molecules in the compounds. The bulk purities of the products were independently confirmed from EA and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements.

elements.content: The single crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pbcm. As a representative example, the crystal structure of 2 is depicted here in detail. Each asymmetric unit contains one zinc atom (Zn3) and one water molecule (O13W) at a general position, two additional zinc atoms (Zn1 and Zn2), and two other water molecules (O1W and O2W) locating at mirror positions (contributing as one-half for each one), and a half X 8– ligand. Every Zn atom coordinates to four carboxylate oxygen atoms at an equatorial position from four different X 8– ligands to form [Zn2(COO)4] paddle wheels that are simplified as red rectangles in Figure a. Each Zn also coordinates to a terminal water molecule in the axial position. The X 8– ligand is linked to eight paddle wheels via bridging carboxylate groups into a slightly distorted rectangular prismatic fashion. The paddle wheels thus serve as 4-connected nodes, whereas the X 8– ligands act as 8-connected nodes, and as expected, both 1 and 2 adopt the known but very rare (4,8)-connected scu topology with the Schlafli symbol {416·612}{44·62}2 (Figure b). They represent the fifth MOFs with scu topology and the third built from an 8-connected bridging ligand.
elements.clean_text: The single crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pbcm. As a representative example, the crystal structure of 2 is depicted here in detail. Each asymmetric unit contains one zinc atom (Zn3) and one water molecule (O13W) at a general position, two additional zinc atoms (Zn1 and Zn2), and two other water molecules (O1W and O2W) locating at mirror positions (contributing as one-half for each one), and a half X  8-  ligand. Every Zn atom coordinates to four carboxylate oxygen atoms at an equatorial position from four different X  8-  ligands to form [Zn2(COO)4] paddle wheels that are simplified as red rectangles in Figure a. Each Zn also coordinates to a terminal water molecule in the axial position. The X  8-  ligand is linked to eight paddle wheels via bridging carboxylate groups into a slightly distorted rectangular prismatic fashion. The paddle wheels thus serve as 4-connected nodes, whereas the X  8-  ligands act as 8-connected nodes, and as expected, both 1 and 2 adopt the known but very rare (4,8)-connected scu topology with the Schlafli symbol {416⋅612}{44⋅62}2 (Figure b). They represent the fifth MOFs with scu topology and the third built from an 8-connected bridging ligand.

elements.content: View of (a) cage A, (b) cage B, (c) cage A was surrounded by eight B cages, (d) cage B was also surrounded by eight A cages, (e) packing of the two cages along the crystallographic a-axis, (f) space-filling model of 2 along the crystallographic a-axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of (a) cage A, (b) cage B, (c) cage A was surrounded by eight B cages, (d) cage B was also surrounded by eight A cages, (e) packing of the two cages along the crystallographic a-axis, (f) space-filling model of 2 along the crystallographic a-axis.

elements.content: The structure of 2 can be viewed as the alternate packing of two types of polyhedral cages A and B in three-dimensional (3D) space. Both the Zn2(COO)4 paddle wheels and the central quaternary carbon atom from the ligands participate in the construction of these two cages. In cage A (Figure a), four Zn2(COO)4 paddle wheel SBUs act as four vertices arranging in a square plane, and two central sp3 carbon atoms from two different ligands act as two other vertices placed at the top and bottom of the slightly distorted octahedron. There are eight triangular faces with shared edges of ca. 9.0 Å (the distance between the centroids of two paddle wheels) in the cage A. One half of them are open, while the others are blocked by the bdc units.
elements.clean_text: The structure of 2 can be viewed as the alternate packing of two types of polyhedral cages A and B in three-dimensional (3D) space. Both the Zn2(COO)4 paddle wheels and the central quaternary carbon atom from the ligands participate in the construction of these two cages. In cage A (Figure a), four Zn2(COO)4 paddle wheel SBUs act as four vertices arranging in a square plane, and two central sp3 carbon atoms from two different ligands act as two other vertices placed at the top and bottom of the slightly distorted octahedron. There are eight triangular faces with shared edges of ca. 9.0 Å (the distance between the centroids of two paddle wheels) in the cage A. One half of them are open, while the others are blocked by the bdc units.

elements.content: Cage B (Figure b) is a distorted cuboctahedron. In cage B, the eight Zn2(COO)4 paddle wheel SBUs and four central quaternary carbon atoms from four different ligands act as 12 vertices of the cuboctahedron. The six distorted rectangular windows with the dimension of ca. 9.4 Å × 8.6 Å are open, while half of the eight triangular faces shared by cage A are blocked by bdc units.
elements.clean_text: Cage B (Figure b) is a distorted cuboctahedron. In cage B, the eight Zn2(COO)4 paddle wheel SBUs and four central quaternary carbon atoms from four different ligands act as 12 vertices of the cuboctahedron. The six distorted rectangular windows with the dimension of ca. 9.4 Å × 8.6 Å are open, while half of the eight triangular faces shared by cage A are blocked by bdc units.

elements.content: The approximate diameter of the inner sphere of cages A and B are 4.0 and 6.0 Å, respectively. Each cage A is surrounded by eight B cages and each cage B is also encompassed by eight cages A via the sharing of triangular faces. Thus, like the structure of CsCl, the network in 2 is constructed by the packing of cage A and cage B in the ratio of 1:1 (Figure c,d). The structure of 2 can be seen that cages A occupy the octahedron space formed by simple cubic packing of cage B (Figure e).
elements.clean_text: The approximate diameter of the inner sphere of cages A and B are 4.0 and 6.0 Å, respectively. Each cage A is surrounded by eight B cages and each cage B is also encompassed by eight cages A via the sharing of triangular faces. Thus, like the structure of CsCl, the network in 2 is constructed by the packing of cage A and cage B in the ratio of 1:1 (Figure c,d). The structure of 2 can be seen that cages A occupy the octahedron space formed by simple cubic packing of cage B (Figure e).

elements.content: As shown in Figures f and, compound 2 possesses one-dimensional square channels of ca. 8.14 × 8.14 Å2 along the crystallographic a-axis, elliptical channels of ca. 10.70 × 10.78 Å2 and 9.40 × 13.15 Å2 along b- and c-axis, respectively. Because of the tetrapodal quality and large size of the ligands, 2 possesses very large solvent accessible volumes of 64.0% of the unit cell volume as calculated by PLATON after removal of free guest molecules in the channels.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figures f and, compound 2 possesses one-dimensional square channels of ca. 8.14 × 8.14 Å2 along the crystallographic a-axis, elliptical channels of ca. 10.70 × 10.78 Å2 and 9.40 × 13.15 Å2 along b- and c-axis, respectively. Because of the tetrapodal quality and large size of the ligands, 2 possesses very large solvent accessible volumes of 64.0% of the unit cell volume as calculated by PLATON after removal of free guest molecules in the channels.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of compound 3; (b) packing of the two cages along the crystallographic c-axis; (c) space-filling packing of 3 along the c direction; (d) (4,8)-connected with scu topology; Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: A –x + 1, –y + 1, z – 1; B x + 1/2, –y + 3/2, –z + 1; C x + 1/2, –y + 3/2, –z + 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination environment of compound 3; (b) packing of the two cages along the crystallographic c-axis; (c) space-filling packing of 3 along the c direction; (d) (4,8)-connected with scu topology; Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: A -x + 1, -y + 1, z - 1; B x + 1/2, -y + 3/2, -z + 1; C x + 1/2, -y + 3/2, -z + 2.

elements.content: When Cd(NO3)2·6H2O was used in place of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O under the same synthetical conditions, compound 3 was obtained. The structure of 3 is also 3D and constructed from the paddle wheel SBUs. Different from compounds 1 and 2, compound 3 crystallizes in tetragonal space group P21212. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains two crystallographically cadmium atoms (Cd1 and Cd2), one-half X 8– ligand, and three coordinate DMF molecules. The two cadmium atoms are quadruply bridged by four carboxylate groups, leading to the construction of distorted [Cd2(COO)4] paddle wheel SBUs. There are also one (O11) and two (O12, O13) DMF molecules coordinated in the axial position of the paddle wheel SBUs. Again, the structure of 3 can also be viewed as the alternatively packing of the cage C (represented as pink balls) and cage D (represented as turquoise balls) with (4,8)-connected scu topology (Figures b,d and ). Although the connectivity of 3 in the 3D space is the same as 2 (both are scu topology), the packing models of 2 and 3 are quite different due to the slight distortion of [Cd2(COO)4] paddle wheel SBUs and the slightly different conformation of the ligands (). The result shows that subtle differences in coordination geometries of metal centers (clusters) may result in extremely different pore shapes and sizes and provide a way to achieve new functional MOFs. The potential solvent accessible volume of 3 is 63.8% of the unit cell volume as calculated by PLATON after removal of coordinate DMF and free guest molecules in the channels.
elements.clean_text: When Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O was used in place of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O under the same synthetical conditions, compound 3 was obtained. The structure of 3 is also 3D and constructed from the paddle wheel SBUs. Different from compounds 1 and 2, compound 3 crystallizes in tetragonal space group P21212. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains two crystallographically cadmium atoms (Cd1 and Cd2), one-half X  8-  ligand, and three coordinate DMF molecules. The two cadmium atoms are quadruply bridged by four carboxylate groups, leading to the construction of distorted [Cd2(COO)4] paddle wheel SBUs. There are also one (O11) and two (O12, O13) DMF molecules coordinated in the axial position of the paddle wheel SBUs. Again, the structure of 3 can also be viewed as the alternatively packing of the cage C (represented as pink balls) and cage D (represented as turquoise balls) with (4,8)-connected scu topology (Figures b,d and ). Although the connectivity of 3 in the 3D space is the same as 2 (both are scu topology), the packing models of 2 and 3 are quite different due to the slight distortion of [Cd2(COO)4] paddle wheel SBUs and the slightly different conformation of the ligands (). The result shows that subtle differences in coordination geometries of metal centers (clusters) may result in extremely different pore shapes and sizes and provide a way to achieve new functional MOFs. The potential solvent accessible volume of 3 is 63.8% of the unit cell volume as calculated by PLATON after removal of coordinate DMF and free guest molecules in the channels.

elements.content: In order to examine the stability of the desolvated samples, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out. The similarity of the PXRD patterns of 1–3 with the simulated PXRD patterns from the single crystal structures, as shown in , suggest their stability with DMF in their channels. However, substitution of the DMF by chloroform and the subsequent removal of the chloroform at room temperature led to the irreversible loss of their crystallinity. This is mainly because of the flexibility of the bridging organic linkers which cannot sustain the frameworks after removal of the guest molecules. To determine whether the three MOFs can uptake polar solvents, solvent exchange was also performed by soaking samples of 1–3 in polar solvents (H2O, MeOH, or EtOH). Unfortunately, the resulting samples had complete loss of crystallinity. These results show that DMF plays a crucial role in sustaining the flexible frameworks.
elements.clean_text: In order to examine the stability of the desolvated samples, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out. The similarity of the PXRD patterns of 1-3 with the simulated PXRD patterns from the single crystal structures, as shown in , suggest their stability with DMF in their channels. However, substitution of the DMF by chloroform and the subsequent removal of the chloroform at room temperature led to the irreversible loss of their crystallinity. This is mainly because of the flexibility of the bridging organic linkers which cannot sustain the frameworks after removal of the guest molecules. To determine whether the three MOFs can uptake polar solvents, solvent exchange was also performed by soaking samples of 1-3 in polar solvents (H2O, MeOH, or EtOH). Unfortunately, the resulting samples had complete loss of crystallinity. These results show that DMF plays a crucial role in sustaining the flexible frameworks.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared three designed MOFs based on flexible tetrahedrally branched octacarboxylate ligands (H 8 X) and [M2(COO)4] paddle wheel SBUs, which possess very rare (4,8)-connected scu topologies. These results demonstrate the promising route of judiciously choosing multidentate ligands as highly connecting vertices and metal ions (clusters) as lower ones to build mixed highly connected MOFs.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have prepared three designed MOFs based on flexible tetrahedrally branched octacarboxylate ligands (H  8  X) and [M2(COO)4] paddle wheel SBUs, which possess very rare (4,8)-connected scu topologies. These results demonstrate the promising route of judiciously choosing multidentate ligands as highly connecting vertices and metal ions (clusters) as lower ones to build mixed highly connected MOFs.

elements.content: Synthesis and general characterization (EA, TGA, and PXRD), crystallographic data in CIF format, and additional structural figures. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title: Designed 4,8-Connected Metal–Organic Frameworks Based on Tetrapodal Octacarboxylate Ligands
